Literature Review: The COVID-19 pandemic has brought unprecedented attention to the use and effectiveness of face masks as a crucial tool in preventing the spread of airborne pathogens. This literature review examines the complex flow physics underlying face mask function and efficacy, synthesizing recent research findings and identifying key areas for future investigation. Face masks operate at the intersection of multiple physical phenomena, including respiratory aerodynamics, filtration mechanics, droplet dynamics, and material interactions. Understanding these processes is essential for optimizing mask design and usage. Respiratory aerodynamics play a fundamental role in mask function, as highlighted by Feng et al. (2020), who used computational fluid dynamics (CFD) simulations to model airflow patterns during breathing and speaking. Their results demonstrated the importance of mask fit in preventing leakage and reducing the risk of pathogen transmission. Filtration efficiency is a critical aspect of face mask performance. Li et al. (2021) conducted experimental studies on various mask materials, revealing that multi-layer designs incorporating both mechanical filtration and electrostatic capture mechanisms offer superior protection against sub-micron particles. This finding underscores the importance of material selection in mask design, as different fabrics exhibit varying levels of filtration efficiency for different particle sizes. Droplet dynamics and their interactions with porous materials are central to understanding mask effectiveness. Verma et al. (2020) used laser light-sheet imaging to visualize respiratory droplet dispersion with and without masks. Their work demonstrated that even simple cloth masks significantly reduce the spread of respiratory droplets, though the extent of reduction varies with mask type and fit. The structural dynamics of face masks during respiration can impact their effectiveness. Tcharkhtchi et al. (2021) investigated the deformation of mask materials under respiratory airflow, finding that excessive deformation can compromise filtration efficiency and increase the risk of leakage. This highlights the need for mask designs that maintain structural integrity under varying respiratory conditions. Human factors and behavior also play a crucial role in mask effectiveness. MacIntyre and Chughtai (2020) reviewed studies on mask adherence and proper usage, emphasizing the importance of education and clear guidelines to maximize the public health benefits of mask-wearing. Their work underscores the need to consider human behavior in addition to physical design when evaluating mask effectiveness. Computational studies have significantly advanced our understanding of face mask performance. Dbouk and Drikakis (2020) used CFD simulations to model droplet dispersion through face masks, providing insights into the impact of mask porosity and fit on transmission risk. Their work demonstrates the potential of computational approaches in optimizing mask design and usage protocols. Experimental measurements remain crucial for validating computational models and assessing real-world mask performance. Konda et al. (2020) conducted comprehensive testing of various fabric combinations, providing valuable data on the filtration efficiencies of different materials across a range of particle sizes. Their findings have informed recommendations for DIY mask construction during periods of commercial mask shortages. Despite significant advances in our understanding of face mask flow physics, several important questions remain. The impact of mask-wearing on long-term respiratory health, particularly in occupational settings, requires further investigation. Additionally, the effectiveness of masks against emerging virus variants with potentially different transmission characteristics needs ongoing assessment. Technical challenges in face mask research include the development of standardized testing protocols that accurately reflect real-world usage conditions. Improving the accuracy of CFD models for complex, multi-phase flows through porous media is another area requiring continued effort. Furthermore, integrating insights from flow physics into practical mask designs that balance effectiveness, comfort, and sustainability remains an important challenge. In conclusion, the flow physics of face masks encompasses a complex interplay of aerodynamics, filtration, material properties, and human factors. Recent research has significantly advanced our understanding of these phenomena, informing public health guidelines and mask design improvements. However, continued research is necessary to address remaining questions and technical challenges, ensuring that face masks remain an effective tool in combating airborne infections and pollutants.
